College of Chemical Engineering, Xiangtan University Xiangtan Hunan 411105 PR China Ni-catalysts are promising candidate for fatty acid hydrodeoxygenation (HDO), but are limited by their quite poor HDO selectivity. Herein, a mesoporous Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst was prepared by precipitation and impregnation method and used for methyl laurate HDO, yielding 96.3% n-dodecane yield at full methyl laurate conversion. Non-edible bio-lipids such as jatropha oil and waste cooking oil also converted to n-C14+16+18 hydrocarbons with yields of 94.3% and 92.4%, respectively. Besides, Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 shows strong chemoselectivity towards the HDO of ester groups. Experimental results showed that Mo-addition and Ti/Si molar ratio strongly influenced HDO selectivity. Oxygen vacancies formed on partial reduced TiO2 surface securely bond Ni NPs and activate CO/CO bonds, improving Ni NPs dispersion and promoting R–COOCH3→R–CHO reduction. Additional, Mo-addition switches reactant adsorption configuration from η1(C)-acyl to η2(C,O)-aldehyde, promoting the formation of R–CH2OH intermediate. Moreover, abundant Brønsted acidic sites (Mo4+–OH, Mo6+–OH, hydroxy groups) facilitate the HDO of R-CH2OH to R-CH3. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Bio-lipids Hydrodeoxygenation Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 catalysts η2(C O)-aldehyde configuration Brønsted acidic sites 1 Introduction Non-edible bio-lipids such as Jatropha oil and waste cooking oil are renewable alternative to petroleum for the production of liquid bio-fuels and value-added compounds [1,2]. But, the liquid bio-fuel derived from bio-lipid transesterification present high oxygen content, resulting in a decrease of fuel quality [3,4]. Thus, oxygen removal is urgently required to meet the standards of transportation fuel with respect to viscosity, cloud point, thermal stability and engine compatibility [5]. With the advancement of petroleum refining infrastructure, hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) has emerged as efficient method for oxygen removal to make this bio-lipid-derived fuel more attractive [6,7]. Metal sulfide catalysts (e.g. CoMoS/Al2O3 and NiMoS/Al2O3) exhibited excellent performance in HDO reaction [8]. However, the co-feeding of sulfur-containing reagent may contaminate the liquid hydrocarbons and give a decrease of fuel quality [9]. Noble metals offer impressive catalytic performance in HDO reaction because of their superior activity of hydrogen activation. However, metal sintering and high cost limit their development [10]. Moreover, noble-metal generally obeys decarbonylation/decarboxylation (DCN/DCX) route rather than HDO path [11]. Thus, scientists have devoted great efforts for developing stable S-free Ni-catalyst for bio-lipids HDO reaction [5]. For example, Pent et al. [12,13] reported the HDO of microalgae oils to renewable hydrocarbons utilizing Ni/ZrO2 catalysts. Foraita et al. converted stearic acid to renewable n-C17 alkanes by a series of Ni/ZrO2 catalysts [14]. Although these catalysts exhibited superior deoxygenation efficiency, the high selectivity (> 95%) toward DCN/DCX route was often observed, lowering the alkane yield due to the carbon loss [15]. Moreover, the high methanation activity of Ni site consumes more hydrogen [16]. Thus, restraining these side-reactions is expected to increase HDO selectivity. An efficient way is to modify Ni nanoparticles (NPs) structure with an oxophilic metal promoter. On account of this view, various Ni-M bimetallic systems such as Ni-Fe, Ni-Co, Ni-Cu, Ni-Sn, Ni-Zn and Ni-Mo have been documented and achieved desirable results [17–21]. Among them, Ni-Mo system stands out and presents a significant increase of HDO selectivity due to the synergy between metallic Ni phase and Mo4+ [22–24]. Unfortunately, such an excellent HDO efficiency was achieved at tough conditions (> 350 ℃), in which CC bond cleavage of hydrocarbon and carbon deposit were more likely occurred at high temperature and subsequently deactivate the catalyst. Yan et al. reported a C15–16 alkanes yield of 97.9% at full conversion of methyl palmitate with a 3% Mo-Ni@PSi(A) catalyst under mild conditions (220 ℃, 1 MPa H2), but the n-C16 yield was only 20.1% [25]. Ding et al. reported that a 56.4% selectivity of n-C18 at full stearic acid conversion was obtained over NiMo/λ-Al2O3-β-zeolite, but was limited by the high reaction temperature (380 ℃) [22]. Therefore, how to design and prepare novel Ni-Mo bimetallic catalyst with high HDO activity under mild condition (≤ 300 ℃) is still a big challenge. Catalyst’s support also has important effect in deoxygenation reactions. Mesoporous γ-Al2O3 is regarded a good support for dispersing Ni NPs owing to its high surface area and porosity [26]. However, the inevitable formation of inert NiAl2O4 spinel phase lowers the hydrogenation activity of Ni sites [27]. To circumvent this shortage, support with redox property would be a promising alternative for Al2O3. TiO2 is a good candidate for Ni sites dispersion and reactants adsorption due to its specific redox properties [28]. The addition of TiO2 into Ni-catalyst generates abundant surface oxygen defects, which simultaneously act as an anchoring site, dispersing the Ni sites almost homogeneously, and as an adsorption site, promoting the activation of CO/C-O. In addition, it has also been evidenced that dispersing active sites on TiO2 surface may positively reduce the activation energy for R-COOH hydrogenation to R-CH2OH [29]. Nevertheless, its low surface area gives rise to easy metal agglomeration and low accessibility to reactant molecules. According to Kordouli’s research [30], the mesoporous Si-Al composite not only minimizes the strong Ni-Al interaction but also allows a higher density of well-dispersed Ni NPs, and greatly promoting the interaction of Ni NPs and reactants. Thus, the as-prepared Ni/Si-Al catalyst exhibited a higher Ni NPs dispersion (3.98 nm) than that of Ni/Al2O3 (7.53 nm), affording an enhanced catalytic performance in phenol HDO reaction. Considering the strong Ni-Al interaction and the advantages of TiO2, however, the synthesis of mesoporous SiO2-TiO2 for Ni NPs anchoring is more advantageous, which is expected to have a higher resistance to metal sintering. Moreover, SiO2-TiO2 brings abundant Brønsted acidic sites and oxygen vacancies [31,32]. The former accelerates the transformation of R-CH2–OH to R–CH3 via hydrogenolysis or dehydration and hydrogenation process [33], while the latter both stabilizes Ni sites and promotes the activation of CO/CO bonds [34,35]. Thereby, combining Ni-Mo bimetallic active sites and SiO2-TiO2 would show an enhanced HDO activity. In addition, in terms of HDO reaction of fatty acid methyl esters (FAMEs), we still lack the knowledge of the role of Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst displayed in reaction path and mechanism. This inspired us to uncover the structure-activity relationship between the intrinsic characteristics and HDO activity of Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst. Moreover, as far as we know, few literatures recorded the use of Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst in bio-lipids HDO reaction. In this research, the Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst was synthesized and adopted for the HDO of methyl laurate (ML), jatropha oil and waste cooking oil to yield renewable alkanes. Under the optimized condition (300 ℃, 3 MPa H2, 6 h), the fresh Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst afforded a 96.3% n-C12 yield at full ML conversion. After 5 consecutive runs, the spent Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst still remained 82.7% n-C12 yield at 91.2% ML conversion, and almost recovered to its initial activity (93.6% n-C12 yield at 97.5% ML conversion) by simple calcination and reduction. Notably, Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst efficiently suppressed DCN/DCX route with less than 4% of C11 existed in the liquid product. According to the analysis of catalyst structure and its HDO performance, we described a simple reaction network and proposed a reasonable catalytic mechanism. This work provided an active and stable Ni-Mo bimetallic catalyst for converting renewable bio-lipids to n-CN alkanes aiming at significantly reducing carbon loss. By reviewing the current literatures in terms of bio-lipids HDO, few works achieved such high HDO selectivity compared to the Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The mesoporous SiO2-TiO2 support was synthesized by co-precipitation method as follows: Firstly, certain amounts of tetrabutyl titanate and tetraethyl orthosilicate were dissolved in distilled water with stirring at 40 ℃ to form a homogeneous solution. Then 37 wt% NH3·H2O was dropped slowly into the solution with stirring until the pH value within 9–10. The obtained precipitate experienced filtration, washing and then drying at 100 ℃ for at least 10 h. Finally, the dried sample was calcined in a muffle furnace (400 °C, 2 ℃/min and 4 h) to obtain a SiO2-TiO2 support. Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 catalysts were prepared by wet co-impregnation method. In a typical procedure, carefully weighted amounts of Ni (CH3COOH)2·6H2O and (NH4)6MoO7·4H2O were dissolved in anhydrous methanol. Then, the mixed solution was impregnated a proper amount of SiO2-TiO2 support with constant stirring (40 ℃, 6 h). After that, excess methanol was removed by rotary evaporation, and the obtained green solid was dried overnight at 100 °C. The Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 precursor was obtained by the calcination of the green solid powder (450 ℃, 2 ℃/min and 6 h). Finally, the precursor oxide was further reduced in H2 atmosphere (30 ML/min, 500 ℃, 5 ℃/min and 2 h) and finally the reduced Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst was obtained. The theoretical Ni loading was 10 wt%, which was the optimum loading based on our previous research [36]. The actual Ni loading was measured by ICP-OES. 2.2 Catalysts characterization Textural properties of Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 were characterized by XRD, Raman, BET, SEM and TEM. The real Ni loading was determined by ICP-OES. The reductive behavior of Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 precursors was revealed by H2-TPR. H2 chemisorption was conducted to measure the Ni NPs dispersion. The catalyst acidity was measured by NH3-TPD experiment. The strength and type of different acidic site were recorded by Py-FTIR spectra. The surface chemical state of Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst was analyzed by XPS measurement. 2.3 Catalytic hydrodeoxygenation and products analysis The catalytic activity assessments for the HDO of ML, other FAMEs and non-edible bio-lipids (jatropha oil and waste cooking oil) were performed in a 100 ML stainless-steel stirred batch reactor. In each test, 0.1 g reduced Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst with 0.5 g reactant in 30 ML cyclohexane was loaded into the reactor. Prior to reaction, pure N2 was employed to replace the residue air inside reactor (5 times) and then the N2 was substituted by H2. Then the reactor was heated to target reaction temperature (300 ℃) with constant stirring (800 rpm). Next, pressure hydrogen (1.5–3.5 MPa) was purged into reactor to start HDO reaction. All the HDO tests were repeated three times to minimize experimental error. The spent Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst was obtained from the reaction mixture by centrifugation and filtration, followed by washing with excess cyclohexane to remove any residual reactants and products and drying in a vacuum oven at 80 ℃ for 6 h to evaporate cyclohexane. The dried Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst was directly used again for HDO reaction under the same operating parameters to investigate the recyclability. After reactor cooled down, the liquid products were collected and sampled for further analysis. The liquid products were quantitatively analyzed by Agilent GC-7890A chromatography (FID, HP-5 capillary column: 30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.25 µm). The column procedure was set as: 70 ℃ (2 min), 70–250 ℃ (20 ℃/min, 4 min). A homemade gas chromatography (FULI 9790H, FID, HP-FFAP capillary column: 30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.25 µm) was employed to quantitatively analyze the concentration of fatty acids. The column procedure was set as: 60 ℃ (2 min), 60–240 ℃ (20 ℃/min, 4 min). n-Eicosane was utilized as the internal standard to quantify the liquid products. The conversion of reactants and the yield of products were calculated by the following equations: (1) Conversion (%) = 1 - Molar amount of reactant after reaction Original Molar amount of reactant × 100 % (2) Yield (%) = Molar mount of product i Total molar amount of products × Conversion The reaction rate was calculated under the conversion of ML below 20%, according to the following equation: 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Fig. 1a shows the XRD patterns of reduced Ni-catalysts. For the Ni/TiO2 catalyst, a series peaks appeared at 25.4°, 37.9°, 48.1°, 53.9°, 55.1°, 62.8°, 68.9°, 70.4°,75.1° and 76.2° are assigned to the reflections of anatase phase (JCPDS 21-1272), while the peaks located at 27.5°, 36.1°, 41.3°, 54.3° and 56.7° are attributed to the reflections of rutile phase (JCPDS 21-1276) [37], and the peaks observed at 44.6° and 51.9° are belonged to the cubic metallic Ni phase (JCPDS 04-0850) [38]. However, after Mo modification, no peaks ascribed to MoO3/MoO2 phases have been observed in the XRD pattern of Ni-Mo/TiO2, indicating a high dispersion of Mo-phase [21]. Similar phenomenon is also observed for Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2. Besides, we noticed that the Mo-addition into Ni-catalyst affects the crystallites of Ni-phase. More precisely, a decrease in the peak intensity of 2θ at 44.6° and 51.9° is observed. These indicate that introducing Mo species presents a certain resistance to Ni NPs aggregation, demonstrating that an interaction of Ni-Mo occurs. Moreover, the Mo-addition shifts the (111) peak of Ni sites from 44.6° to 44.2°, implying the doping of Mo into Ni lattice which also supports the occurrence of Ni-Mo interaction [39]. As for the Ni/SiO2-TiO2 and Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2, we can clearly see that these two catalysts exhibit a very broad and weak peak around 25° which is related to the amorphous SiO2, and no peaks belonged to TiO2 phases are observed, meaning that the introduction of SiO2 restrains the growth of TiO2 particles [32]. By comparing with the other three Ni-based catalysts, the Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 shows the lowest peak intensity of Ni phase, meaning the highest dispersion of Ni site has been achieved. The mean size of Ni calculated from Debye-Scherrer equation followed the following order: Ni/TiO2 (16.7 nm) > Ni-Mo/TiO2 (14.3 nm) > Ni/SiO2-TiO2 (8.4 nm) > Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 (6.7 nm), suggesting that the co-introduction of Mo and Si into Ni-catalyst improve the Ni NPs dispersion. Raman spectroscopy was employed to gain more TiO2 structure information. As shown in Fig. 1b, the Ni/TiO2 and Ni-Mo/TiO2 catalysts both exhibit five Raman shifts: 158, 215, 409, 523 and 644 cm−1, belonging to Eg (O-Ti-O symmetric stretching vibration), B1g (O-Ti-O symmetric bending vibration), A1g (O-Ti-O antisymmetric bending vibration) and Eg modes of classical TiO2 anatase phase [31]. Besides, for the Ni-Mo/TiO2 sample, the introduction of Mo species increases the Raman shift of Eg mode from 158 to 163 cm−1 owing to the formation of surface defects (Ti3+) and/or oxygen vacancies. Moreover, the higher peak intensity of Ni-Mo/TiO2 catalyst demonstrates an enrichment of oxygen vacancies on the TiO2 particles surface [40]. These results indicate that Mo-addition promotes the reduction of TiO2 and forms more oxygen vacancies as compared to single Ni/TiO2. The introduction of Mo into Ni/TiO2 increases Ni dispersion and thus enhances the capacity of H2 dissociation accompanied by the formation of abundant active hydrogen (H*) species. Therefore, the H* spillover from Ni site to TiO2 surface is promoted and helps to form more oxygen vacancies [41]. For the Ni/SiO2-TiO2 and Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 samples, no detectable Raman signals are recorded, indicating that the growth of TiO2 species in the two Ni-catalysts are restrained by the amorphous SiO2, in accordance with previous research [42] and XRD results (Fig. 1a). According to the analysis of catalyst crystal structure (Fig. 1), it can be seen that introducing Mo has minor effect on the phase variation of the Ni-Mo bimetallic catalysts, whereas Si-addition remarkably reduces Ni-Mo catalysts crystallinity. This change intimated that catalyst morphology may experience an obvious variation. As shown in Fig. 2a, the Ni/TiO2 catalyst is mainly consist of irregular block structure, and the catalyst morphology is basically maintained when introducing Mo into Ni/TiO2 system. Besides, gaps between particles are clearly observed for both Ni/TiO2 and Ni-Mo/TiO2, which is disadvantageous for increasing catalyst surface area and resultantly giving low active sites dispersion. In contrast, when introducing SiO2 into Ni/TiO2 or Ni-Mo/TiO2, the catalyst morphology changes from irregular block to small sphere-like structure (Fig. 2b,d), which is in line with Foraita’s finding that catalyst with smaller particle size brings benefits for achieving large surface area [43]. These changes are closely related to the variation of catalyst crystallinity that SiO2-addition makes the XRD diffraction peaks became broader and weaker. Moreover, the transformation of catalyst morphology will in turn affect catalyst intrinsic natures such as porosity and metal dispersion. Fig. 3 shows the N2 sorption isotherms and pore size distribution of Ni/TiO2, Ni-Mo/TiO2, Ni/SiO2-TiO2 and Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2. It’s clearly seen that the four Ni-catalysts all present a similar hysteresis loop, in which P/Po ratio in the range of 0.4–0.95. N2 adsorption at lower P/Po region was not observed, indicating all the four Ni-based catalysts are mesoporous materials. Interestingly, the Ni/TiO2 and Ni-Mo/TiO2 catalysts exhibit H3 type hysteresis, whereas hysteresis loop on Ni/SiO2-TiO2 and Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 samples are ascribed to H2 type hysteresis. These suggesting that mesopores in Ni/SiO2-TiO2 and Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 are more uniformly dispersed than the rest two Ni-catalysts, in accordance with the observation of SEM images (Fig. 2). This point is also supported by the narrow pore size distribution of Ni/SiO2-TiO2 and Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 (Fig. 3b). In contrast, the broad and complex pore size distribution of Ni/TiO2 and Ni-Mo/TiO2 catalysts demonstrated that gaps between particles with various shapes (plates, cubes, rods or spheres) accounted for the majority. Textural properties of fresh catalysts are shown in Table 1. Introducing Mo into Ni/TiO2 slightly decreases catalyst surface area and pore size from 123 to 107 cm2/g and 14.5–12.3 nm, respectively. However, after introducing a certain amount of SiO2, the surface area dramatically increased from 123 (Ni/TiO2) to 248 m2/g (Ni/SiO2-TiO2) and 107 (Ni-Mo/TiO2) to 225 m2/g (Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2), whereas there pore size decreased from 14.5 to 4.9 nm and 12.3 to 5.1 nm, respectively. This phenomenon would ascribe to the excellent capacity of mesopore generation of SiO2, in accordance with the previous research [30]. Foraita et al. stated that increasing SiO2 content significantly increased catalyst SBET value from 72 (Ni/ZrO2) to 193 m2/g (Ni/37SiO2-ZrO2) [43]. Lu et al. increased the Si/Ti molar ratio from 0 to 2/1 in Ni/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst and achieved higher surface area (223 m2/g) than that of Ni/TiO2 (100 m2/g), which is beneficial for increasing Ni NPs dispersion [32]. Moreover, the increasing surface area by Si introduction allows more metal sites to disperse on catalyst surface and thus leading to different Ni NPs dispersion. As shown in Fig. 4A1–D1, the mean size of Ni NPs decreases in the order of: Ni/TiO2 (15.17 nm) > Ni-Mo/TiO2 (13.42 nm) > Ni/SiO2-TiO2 (9.15 nm) > Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 (7.36 nm). H2-chemisorption was used to determine the Ni NPs dispersion on catalysts surface, as summarized in Table 1, which are 1.74%, 1.92%, 2.77% and 3.36% for Ni/TiO2, Ni-Mo/TiO2, Ni/SiO2-TiO2 and Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2, respectively. It demonstrates that the introduction of Si and Mo is conducive to improve Ni NPs dispersion. The difference in Ni NPs dispersion would be attributed to several aspects: (i) the addition of oxophilic Mo affects Ni electron density, which is closely related to the Ni NPs dispersion; (ii) the increase of catalyst surface area by Si introduction allows more metal sites to disperse on catalyst surface and thus result in an increase of Ni NPs dispersion; (iii) the introduction of Si and Mo increase the amounts of catalyst acidic sites, which Ni NPs preferentially interact with acidic centers to form robust Ni sites, leading to high dispersion of Ni NPs. HR-TEM images (Fig. 4A2–D2) show the Ni NPs anchoring on the TiO2 surface: the lattice fringe of 0.201 nm attributes to Ni(111) plane; while that of ~ 0.350 nm is ascribed to the TiO2(101) plane. In this case, the Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst achieved the finest Ni NPs dispersion, large surface area and appropriate acidity. As compared to the Ni/TiO2 catalyst, the oxophilic promoter (Mo), surface area and catalyst acidity present more advantageous for increasing Ni NPs dispersion. In order to further investigate the reductive behaviors of the four Ni-catalysts, H2-TPR experiments were conducted ( Fig. 5). As shown in the Fig. 5, the Ni/TiO2 sample exhibited two H2 consumption peaks: the first one (α) centered at 363 ℃ is belonged to the reduction of amorphous NiO species which weakly interact with TiO2 support [38]; the second one (β) located at 410 ℃ is ascribed to the reduction of well-dispersed Ni sites which present strong interaction with TiO2 [44]. When 3 wt% Mo is introduced into Ni/TiO2, the position of β shifts to higher region (410→457), while the α peak also shows a slight positive shift (363→386). This observation indicates that the addition of Mo-phase restrains the aggregation of Ni NPs due to the enhanced interaction between Ni and TiO2 or Ni and MoOx species. Nevertheless, the H2 consumption of α peak remains almost unchanged or a bitter larger as compared to Ni/TiO2, indicating the existence of large amounts of amorphous NiO species which are facilely to aggregate to form larger Ni NPs and consequently lowering the catalytic performance [45]. Moreover, a weak peak at 549 ℃ (λ) was also observed, which is attributed to the reduction of TiO2 species (Ti4+ to Ti3+) accompanied by the formation of oxygen vacancies, in agreement with Xu’s report [38]. However, we did not observe the reduction peak of MoOx species for all the Mo-containing samples probably due to the low content of Mo as compared to that of Ni [30]. As for the H2-TPR file of Ni/SiO2-TiO2, the β peak becomes dominant, while the α peak weakens significantly. This means that large surface area by SiO2 introduction allows TiO2 to more homogeneously dispersed, increasing the accessibility of Ni NPs to TiO2 and then enhancing the interaction of Ni and TiO2. In the case of Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2, we noticed the absence of α peak and a positive shift of β peak (455→475), meaning a further enhanced interaction of Ni-MoOx/Ni-TiO2 occurred. Additionally, the Mo-addition also promotes the reduction of TiO2, which is evidenced by the negative shift of γ peak (611→597), in accordance with the reductive behavior of Ni-Mo/TiO2 compared to Ni/SiO2-TiO2. It can be summarized that the co-introduction of Mo and SiO2 not only increases catalyst surface area, but also promotes the reduction of Ti4+ to Ti3+ with oxygen vacancy for Ni NPs anchoring, thus obtaining small Ni NPs with fine dispersion, in consistent with our XRD, Raman data and TEM images. 3.1.1 NH3-TPD Fig. 6a displays the NH3-TPD profiles of the four Ni-catalysts. Ni/TiO2 catalyst exhibits two NH3 desorption peaks: an intense peak (172 ℃) ascribed to weak acidic sites and a very weak peak (598 ℃) belonged to strong acidic centers. Similar profile is observed for Ni-Mo/TiO2 catalyst, but an increase of catalyst strong acidity is observed when Mo species are introduced to Ni/TiO2 catalyst. This indicates that Mo-addition increase catalyst strong acidity, and the increased metal acidic sites (Mo4+ and Mo6+) may account for this increase [46]. As for the Ni/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst, except for the appearance of weak medium acidic centers (352), a novel peak located at 574 ℃ is observed. This novel peak is related to strong interaction of NH3 and the Si-OH and/or bridge -OH groups which are always served as Brønsted acidic sites. This undoubtedly increases catalyst total acidity. Notably, after modification by Mo, the Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 shows an obvious increase of catalyst total acidity. As mentioned above, Mo-addition promotes the reduction of TiO2 during the reduction process and thus generates more Ti3+ acidic sites (Lewis). Besides, high surface area by Si-addition generates more well-dispersed Mo species, promoting Mo6+→Mo4+→Mo0 reduction and increasing the dispersity of metal acidic sites and resultantly enhancing the Ni-MoOx and/or Ni-TiO2 interaction. This would bring benefits to expose more acid sites, including Brønsted acid sites (Si-OH, bridge -OH, Mo4+-OH and Mo6+-OH) and Lewis acid (Niδ+, Ti3+, Ti4+, Mo4+ and Mo6+) sites on catalyst surface (see Fig. 6b). As shown in Table 2, the co-introduction of Mo and Si increases both catalyst total acidity and Brønsted acidity. The total acidity decreased in the order: Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 (0.058 mmol/g) > Ni/SiO2-TiO2 (0.041 mmol/g) > Ni-Mo/TiO2 (0.034 mmol/g) > Ni/TiO2 (0.021 mmol/g), while the B/L ratio followed the order of: Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 (0.310) > Ni/SiO2-TiO2 (0.253) > Ni-Mo/TiO2 (0.197) > Ni/TiO2 (0.146). To summary, the co-introduction of Mo and Si enrich the density of acidic sites on catalyst, especially the increased Brønsted acidity. XPS technique was performed investigate the chemical state of elements and their interaction on catalyst surface structure. As shown in Fig. 7a, four peaks near 852.6, 854.1, 856.0 and 861.2 eV are detected and ascribed to Ni0, Ni2+, and their satellite peaks respectively [38]. Notably, the binding energy (BE) of metallic Ni phase shifts to lower region when Mo and Si are introduced into Ni/TiO2 catalyst. The BE value of Ni0 decreased in the order of: Ni/TiO2 (852.6 eV) > Ni-Mo/TiO2 (852.3 eV) > Ni/SiO2-TiO2 (851.9 eV) > Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 (851.2 eV) ( Table 3). This indicates the occurrence of stronger interactions of Ni-Mo and Ni-TiO2 accompanied by the electron transfer (TiOx→Ni and/or Mo→Ni), in agreement with the results of XRD and Raman data. This confirms that Ni sites on Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 possess the highest electron density among the four Ni-based catalysts. Moreover, the enhancement of Ni-Mo and Ni-TiO2 interaction and catalyst porosity achieve a high Ni NPS dispersion: Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 (85.0%) > Ni/SiO2-TiO2 (77.7%) > Ni-Mo/TiO2 (66.7) > Ni/TiO2 (57.2%), which guarantees that abundant Ni sites are accessible for H2 dissociation and Cδ+ adsorption (CO/C-O). Fig. 7b displays Ti 2p spectra of the four reduced Ni-catalysts. These catalysts all exhibit a broad Ti 2p3/2 peak centered at ~ 458.6 eV. By deconvoluting this broad peak, two peaks at ∼459.1 and ∼ 458.5 eV were obtained and attributed to Ti4+ and Ti3+ chemical state. It should be noted that amount of Ti3+ species (Table 3) gradually increases from Ni/TiO2 to Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2, suggesting the enrichment of enhancement of oxygen vacancies. Moreover, the shift of Ti3+ binding energy to lower region suggests the facile formation of oxygen vacancy. Fig. 7c presents the deconvolution results of O1s species, in which three deconvoluted peaks are appeared at ~ 529.3, ~ 530.4 and ~ 531.6 eV and assigned to lattice oxygen, oxygen vacancy and surface -OH group. The Mo-addition shows a promotion effect on oxygen vacancy concentration which exhibits a similar trend found in Ti 2p3/2 spectra. The Si modification significantly increases the concentration of surface hydroxyl group, which can be served as Brønsted acid sites for promoting the transformation process of R–CH2OH→R–CH3. As for the Mo 3d XPS (Fig. 7d), the spectrum of Ni-Mo/TiO2 can be fitted into six peaks at 227.6 eV (Mo0), 228.3 eV (Mo4+), 230.5 eV (Mo0), 231.6 eV (Mo4+), 232.3 eV (Mo6+) and 234.9 eV (Mo6+). Notably, Mo0 content obviously increases from 12.2% (Ni-Mo/TiO2) to 23.3% (Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2), demonstrating that catalyst porosity enhancement affords higher dispersion of Mo than that of Ni-Mo/TiO2 and is more facilely to be reduced to form more oxophilic sites. Moreover, Mo0 peaks slightly shift to high BE region from of 227.3 (Ni-Mo/TiO2) to 227.7 eV (Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2), and further to 230.5 (Ni-Mo/TiO2) to 230.8 eV (Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2), implying negative charge transfer from Mo to Ni. As mentioned above, the contents of electron-rich Ni, oxygen vacancy and surface are positively influenced by the enhanced interactions of Ni-Mo and Ni-TiO2, while abundant hydroxyl groups originates from the co-introduction of Mo and Si. These results are in accordance with the results of H2-TPR and XRD data. Therefore, as shown in Table 3, the Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst shows the highest ratio of electron-rich Ni, oxygen vacancy and surface -OH group. 3.2 Catalytic performance Fig. 8 A displays the influence of reaction time on ML conversion and product distribution over 10 wt%Ni-3 wt%Mo/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst. An 82.3% ML conversion was obtained at the first 2 h, however, the n-C12 yield was only 42.7%. Besides the unreacted ML molecule and the main product n-C12 formed by HDO route, large amounts of lauric acid and dodecanol were still remained in the liquid products. In addition, we also noticed that a small amount of n-C11 alkanes (1.2%) was produced in liquid phase. This observation indicated that the DCN and DCX paths were greatly suppressed, whereas the HDO route is obviously promoted. As a result, increasing the reaction time from 2 to 4 h helped to enhance the ML conversion from 82.3% to 93.4% and simultaneously increase the n-C12 yield from 42.7% to 80.4%. Further increase of reaction time to 6 h continuously brings an increase in ML conversion (93.4–100%) and n-C12 yield (80.4–96.3%). As the reaction time was further increased to 8 h or even 10 h, the ML conversion maintain the same level, but the n-C12 yield decreased from 96.3% to 91.7% and 87.4%, respectively. In contrast, the C10 and Cn (n ≤ 9) alkanes were increased from 0.5% to 3.98% and 1.7% to 6.82%, respectively. This is mainly ascribed to the hydrocracking reaction which is favored by long-term reaction process at high temperature, leading to the CC bonds cleavage of hydrocarbons and subsequently producing light alkanes [47]. Interestingly, cracked products was not detected at the early stage of the reaction, indicating that the great reaction priority would be given to HDO route rather than CC bond scission when CC bond cleavage competes with HDO reaction. Fig. 8 B shows the impact of reaction temperature on HDO performance of 10 wt%Ni-3 wt%Mo/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst. The Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst exhibited a poor HDO efficiency at relative low temperature, affording an n-C12 yield of 20% at 65.7% ML conversion owing to the shortage of activation energy for CO bond scission in –COOCH3 to generate dodecanal intermediates. As the temperature increased to 280 ℃, the ML conversion and n-C12 yield significantly increased to 94.9% and 81.9%, respectively. As the temperature further rose to 300 ℃, the n-C12 yield reached its maximum value (96.3%) at full ML conversion. These results indicated that the increase of temperature promotes the conversion of R–CH2OH to R–CH3, consistent with previous literatures [3,48]. In addition, this value of n-C12 yield is higher than many reported Ni-Mo bimetallic catalysts when they conducted bio-lipid HDO reaction. However, when the reaction temperature increased to 320 ℃, it gave a higher yield of C10 (4%) and Cn (n ≤ 9) (6.8%) alkanes due to the CC bond cleavage which in agreement with Li’s research that cracking reaction is more likely occurred at harsh conditions [47]. Nevertheless, the major product is still C12 hydrocarbon (87.4%), indicating that the increase of temperature contributes more to HDO route than CC bond scission. Therefore, from the above results, the combination of 300 ℃ and 6 h was selected as the optimal condition for the next study. The influence of H2 pressure on HDO performance of 10 wt%Ni-3 wt%Mo/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst was explored, as shown in Fig. 8C. When the reaction was conducted under 1.5 MPa at 300 ℃, though the ML conversion was as high as 94%, the n-C12 yield was only 38.3% accompanied by 34.8% yield to dodecanol intermediate. From the abovementioned results, considering the large amounts of dodecanol formed at early stage of HDO reaction, we postulated that dodecanol would be the key intermediate for the HDO mechanism. This is mainly because that energy barrier for R–CH2OH→R–CH3 conversion is higher than that of R–COOH→R–CHO. To validate this hypothesis, we performed another independent HDO test with dodecanol as reactant. As expected, a 96.5% yield of n-C12 at full dodecanol conversion was obtained over 10 wt%Ni-3 wt%Mo/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst. This observation strongly proves that the acceleration of R–CH2OH→R–CH3 process greatly increases the n-C12 yield. Further increasing H2 pressure to 2.5 MPa remarkably increased n-C12 yield to 96.3%, meaning a promotion effect of H2 pressure on HDO selectivity, in accordance with Ni’s research [49]. However, further increasing H2 pressure from 2.5 to 3.5 MPa, a slight decrease of n-C12 yield was observed, whereas the content of cracked products slightly increased from increased 2.2–3.9%. This maybe because higher pressure may finish the HDO reaction in a shorter time (< 6 h), resulting in the occurrence of CC bond cleavage in the remaining time. Thus, the combination of 300 ℃, 2.5 MPa H2 and 6 h is adopted as the optimized conditions for the following HDO reaction. Fig. 8D shows the effect of Ti/Si molar ratio on catalytic performance of Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst. When Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 with small Ti/Si values (0/1) was utilized for ML HDO reaction, the n-C12 yield is no more than 53%, whereas the n-C12 yield increased to 96.3% as the Ti/Si molar ratio increased to 1/1, accompanied by an increase of ML conversion from 90.4% to 100%. In contrast, the n-C11 yield decreased from 15.5% to 1.5% when the value of Ti/Si molar ratio reached 1/1. However, further increasing Ti/Si molar ratio not only decreased the ML conversion (100→72.7%) but also lowered the n-C12 yield (96.3→42.7%) when the Ti/Si increased from 1/1–1/0. These results indicated that the Ti/Si molar ratio strongly influences the activity and chemoselectivity of Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst during HDO reaction. As we mentioned above, an appropriate Ti/Si molar ratio would maximized the catalytic performance of Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 due to the following advantages: (i) increasing catalyst surface area to allow more Ni sites uniformly dispersed; (ii) forming more oxygen vacancy on catalyst surface for CO/CO bond adsorption and Ni sites anchoring; and (iii) increased acidic sites density for accelerating the conversion of R–CH2–OH to R–CH3. These advantages show benefits for the significant increase of ML conversion and n-C12 yield as the Ti/Si ratio increased from 0/1 to 1/1. However, further increasing Ti/Si ratio to 1/0 obviously decreases catalyst surface area from 225 to 107 m2/g (Table 1). This decline in surface area undoubtedly decreases Ni sites dispersion and reduces the accessibility of reactant to active sites, thus decreasing catalyst HDO efficiency. In addition, the loss of surface area reduces catalyst porosity, making Ni sites more facilely aggregate to larger Ni NPs with poor hydrogenation ability (Fig. 4) [12]. Moreover, the increase of Ti/Si ratio also decreases the amounts of Brønsted acidic sites, as evidenced by Py-IR spectra (Fig. 6b, Table 2), which shows negative effect on R–CH2–OH to R–CH3 conversion and consequently lowers the n-C12 yield. In contrast, the n-C11 yield increased from 1.5% to 22.9% as the Ti/Si ratio increases from 1/1 to 1/0. This is mainly because that the acid sites of TiO2 are mainly consisted of Lewis acidic sites which favor DCN/DCX route rather than HDO path. Papageridis et al. reported a similar conclusion that the decreased HDO selectivity of Ni/Al2O3 is attributed to the absence of Brønsted acidity [50]. Fig. 8E displays the comparison of ML conversions and alkane yields over the four Ni-catalysts. As compared to the single Ni/TiO2 catalyst, the Mo-addition gives an increase of 22.3% in ML conversion, while the introduction of SiO2 increases the ML conversion from 50.4% to 81.5%. Notably, the simultaneous introduction of Mo and Si into Ni/TiO2 catalyst remarkably raises the ML conversion to 100%. Thus, the addition of Mo and Si to Ni catalysts enhances the catalyst activity. Moreover, to get more insights of the catalyst activity, we performed the calculations of reaction rate and TOF value. As shown in Table 1, the reaction rate decreases in the following order: Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 (9.18 mmolML g−1 cat h−1) > Ni/SiO2-TiO2 (5.65 mmolML g−1 cat h−1) > Ni-Mo/TiO2 (3.64 mmolML g−1 cat h−1) > Ni/TiO2 (2.18 mmolML g−1 cat h−1). Similar trend is also observed for the TOF value, which reduces in the sequence: Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 (158 h−1) > Ni/SiO2-TiO2 (123 h−1) > Ni-Mo/TiO2 (109 h−1) > Ni/TiO2 (76 h−1). These results further confirmed that the co-introduction of Si and Mo greatly enhances the catalyst performance. Over the four Ni-catalysts synthesized for the HDO of ML, n-C11 and n-C12 are mainly obtained from ML HDO. The Ni-catalyst modified by Mo exhibits an increase in the total alkanes yield and simultaneously increases n-C12 selectivity. This promotion effect in n-C12 selectivity is significantly high over the Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst, revealing that there may be a synergism between Mo and SiO2 which shows a positive effect on the enhancement of HDO selectivity. HDO of renewable bio-lipids to produce high-quality hydrocarbons is a hot topic issue in recent literatures. Ni NPs supported on various supports (e.g. Al2O3 [51], SiO2 [1], ZrO2 [49], ZnO-Al2O3 [16,52], SBA-15 [53], zeolites [54,55]) have drawn great attention due to the availability of this cheap metal and its noble-like hydrogenation ability. However, n-CN-1 alkanes are always formed through DCN/DCX routes by these catalysts. Kordouli et al. proved that introducing Mo into Ni-catalyst enhances the HDO selectivity, which is closely related to the Ni-Mo interaction [21]. In this case, Mo-addition increases the amounts of Brønsted acidic sites (Mo6+-OH and Mo4+-OH), which accelerates the transformation of R–CH2OH to R–CH3. Besides, the oxophilic MoOx phases vary the interaction between reactant molecule and catalyst surface from η1(C)-acyl and/or carboxylate to η2(C,O)-aldehyde configuration which is more stable and facile to be attacked by active hydrogen to form R–CH2OH intermediate. Moreover, charge transfer from Mo atom to Ni atom promotes the dissociation of hydrogen and then the hydrogenation of R-COOH to R-CHO (rate-determining step). What’s more, Ni-Mo interaction helps to enhance the activation of COH bond of alcohol intermediate and thus increases HDO selectivity. Nevertheless, we noticed that the increase of Ni electron density on Ni-Mo/ZrO2 is only 0.3 eV. This moderate increase of Ni electron density preferentially cleaves the –C–CHO to produce n-CN-1 alkanes, whereas Ni atom with excess higher electron density prefers the hydrogenation of –C–CHO to –CH2–CH2OH [49]. Therefore, though the ML conversion and HDO selectivity was improved by increasing Mo species, the main product in the obtained liquid alkanes was still n-C11. The low surface area of Ni-Mo/TiO2 may account for its relative low catalytic performance (61.8%). In contrast, the introduction of Si increases catalyst surface area and additionally gives a rise of Brønsted acidic sites. Thus, the growth of TiO2 is constricted and highly well-dispersed Ni NPs and Mo oxide phase are obtained. As a result, the co-introduction of Mo and Si presents the opportunity to simultaneously enhance HDO efficiency through a higher concentration of oxygen vacancies, an enhanced Ni-Mo and/or Ni-TiO2 interaction, an increased Brønsted acidity and a higher Ni electron density. As shown in Fig. 8F, the Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst exhibited certain catalytic stability, maintaining 91.2% of ML conversion after fifth consecutive runs. Nevertheless, a 13.6% decrease in n-C12 yield was still observed for Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 during the recyclability test, and this behavior is not satisfactory. After simple calcination (300 ℃) and reduction (500 ℃), the activity of spent Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 almost recovered to its original level (93.6% n-C12 yield at 97.5% ML conversion). This result indicates that the deposition of amorphous carbon on catalyst surface species may account for the activity loss. To confirm this deduce, Raman spectra was employed to identify the carbon species deposited on catalyst surface. Fig. S1 exhibits two characteristic peaks, one broad band emerged at 1338 cm−1 (D-band) is attributed to sp2-bonded carbon, while another narrow band appeared at 1585 cm−1 (G-band) is related to the phonons of A1 g and E2g symmetry. It’s well accepted that higher ID/IG ratio is associated to lower degree of carbon deposit. Thus, the calculated ID/IG ratio for Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 is 2.93, implying the coke formed on catalyst surface is mainly consist of amorphous carbon species which can be easily removed by calcination. Moreover, TEM image of spent Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 showed slight Ni NPs aggregation which also contributes to the catalyst deactivation (Fig. S2). Therefore, in our future work, considerable efforts will be devoted to developing more stable Ni-Mo bimetallic catalysts. The excellent chemoselectivity of Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 was further investigated by using different model compounds, affording yields of the corresponding n-alkanes of more than 95% from methyl decanoate, methyl myristate, methyl palmitate and methyl stearate (Table S1, entries 1–5). In addition, the HDO of non-edible jatropha oil and waste cooking oil were also conducted to evaluate the HDO performance of Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2. As displayed in Table S1 (entries 6 and 7), The Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 yielded 94.3% yield of n-C14+16+18 alkanes for the HDO of jatropha oil. As for the HDO of waste cooking oil, 92.4% yield of n-C14+16+18 alkanes was obtained. These results firmly demonstrated that Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 material showed superior catalytic activity and selectivity towards renewable bio-lipids HDO reaction, and efficiently suppressed DCN/DCX routes. Moreover, we also compared our results with the reported literatures. As shown in Table S2, though the most of reported Ni-Mo bimetallic catalysts showed excellent HDO activity, their selectivity toward HDO product is relative low (< 80%). Nevertheless, the Ni-Mo/H-ZSM-5 catalyst showed 95% yield of n-C18 at full stearic acid conversion under mild condition (260 ℃) (Table S2, entry 5). However, the high H2 pressure and longer reaction time may additionally increase the cost and limit its industrial application. 3.3 Reaction network and catalytic deoxygenation mechanism of ML According to the aforementioned discussion and analysis, we proposed a simple but reasonable reaction path of ML HDO (see Fig. 9). The major route for producing n-C12 is HDO. As seen in Fig. 9, ML firstly converts to lauric acid by hydrogenolysis and then hydrogenated to dodecanal (path 1 to path 2) or directly transformed to dodecanal and simultaneously yield CH3OH (path 3). Next, Ni sites on Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 excess electron density catalyzes the hydrogenation of dodecanal to dodecanol (path 6) rather than DCN to yield n-C11 alkane (path 5). The DCX of lauric acid also contributes to the yield of n-C11 alkanes (path 4). However, the DCX process is most favored by noble-metal. Jiraroj et al. reported a selective DCX process of oleic acid over Ni-FSM-16 and obtained 75% C17 alkanes [56]. Rashidi et al. prepared a Ni-Co/SBA-15 catalyst for DCX of waste cooking oil [57], while Yang et al. achieved DCX of oleic acid over Ni-BM 65 MOF/zeolite 5A catalyst [58]. However, the reaction temperatures adopted in these cases are much higher than that of Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 (300 ℃), implying that high-temperature promotes the occurrence of DCX which is in agreement with zhang’s report [59]. Nevertheless, in this catalytic system, we cannot exclude the possibility of fatty acid decarboxylation to produce n-C11, but regard it as a possible path. Besides, reversed pathway (path 7 to path 5) may also yield n-C11, but, the path 7 is greatly restricted due to the addition of oxophilic Mo promoter and enhanced Brønsted acidity. The former help to adsorb O-atom and activate CO bond of R–CH2–OH, while the later promote the protonation of –OH. Moreover, the significant difference between n-C12 yield (> 95%) and n-C11 yield (< 2%) using dodecanol as raw material also supported this conclusion. After that, dodecanol can further convert to n-C12 by direct hydrogenolysis (path 10) or sequential dehydration-hydrogenation (path 8 to path 9). However, the dodecene is not detected by our GC instrument because of the much lower activation energy of dodecene→dodecane than that of dodecanol→dodecane [60]. Moreover, the abundant acidic sites on the Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst surface (especially the Brønsted acidic site) may also convert alcohols to dodecyl laurate and/or dodecyl ether [61]. The presence of decane and lower alkanes indicates the occurrence of the minor amount of hydrocracking which could be the consequence of hydrogenolysis (the removal of terminal methyl group in the form of methane over the reduced Ni NPs [15]) or ideal hydrocracking due to the bifunctional properties of the catalyst including both acidic and hydrogenation/dehydrogenation functions [62]. Based on the analysis of reaction network, the structure and intrinsic natures of Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst, the catalytic HDO mechanism of ML were proposed as shown in Fig. 10. As mentioned above, among the four Ni-catalysts, the active site diversity on Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 surface is more abundant than the other three Ni-catalysts, which is crowded with Ni0 site, metal cations, oxygen vacancies and surface hydroxyl groups. This enhancement greatly promotes the sequential HDO reaction. As reported in other researches, R-CH2OH has been confirmed as an important intermediate in the fatty acid HDO reaction, which itself is formed via the hydrogenation of surface-adsorbed R-CHO species. The higher concentration of R-CHO species produced in the selective hydrogenation of R-COOH with Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 could, thereby, contribute to the increased R-CH3 yield by increasing the density of surface-adsorbed R-CH2OH species. Peng et al. demonstrated that the hydrogenation of R-COOH to R-CHO species on the catalyst surface would occur more easily by increasing Ni NPs dispersion [63]. The Ni NPs dispersion for the four Ni-catalysts used in this work decreased in the order: Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 > Ni/SiO2-TiO2 > Ni-Mo/TiO2 > Ni/TiO2. The more uniform dispersion of Ni NPs on Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 surface provides more H2 dissociation sites across the catalyst surface, contributing to enhanced activity of R-COOH→R-CHO. However, R-CHO adsorbs on pure Ni surface preferentially forms η1(C)-acyl configuration which is more facilely to form n-CN-1 alkanes by direct DCN/DCX and simultaneously to produce CO/CO2. Actually, in our Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst surface, we observed an enhanced Ni-Mo and/or Ni-TiO2 interaction which accelerates the electron transfer from Mo to Ni or from TiO2 support to Ni via the Ni-OV-TiOx interface [64]. Therefore, the Ni site on Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 surface with excess electron density gives higher selectivity towards R-CHO to R-CH2OH instead of cleavage of CCHO bond [49]. Moreover, with the assistance of oxophilic Mo, the configuration of CO adsorbed on catalyst surface switches from η1(C)-acyl to η2(C,O)-aldehyde, where Cδ+ and Oδ− atoms in Cδ+ Oδ− preferentially adsorb on Ni and Mo atoms, respectively. Once η2(C,O)-aldehyde has formed, the active hydrogen (H*) formed by dissociation of H2 on the adjacent Ni site immediately attacks the activated CO bond to yield dodecanol intermediate. Finally, the abundant Brønsted acidic sites (Mo4+-OH, Mo6+-OH, Si-OH, bridge –OH) on catalyst surface drive the protonation of –OH to yield –OH2 +, promoting the conversion of R–CH2OH→R–CH3 by dehydration and hydrogenation. Of course, CO bond hydrogenolysis also contributes to the high yield of n-alkanes. Notably, high density of oxygen vacancy on Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst surface not only help stabilize the Ni site, but also as potential oxophilic site help activate the CO/CO bond. In summary, introducing small amounts of oxophilic Mo into single Ni catalyst favors the adsorption of CO/C–O in the η2(C,O) configuration, and resultantly increases the selectivity of HDO pathway. 4 Conclusion Mesoporous SiO2-TiO2 supported Ni-Mo bimetallic catalysts, which were prepared by precipitation and impregnation, are evidenced to be active toward the HDO of bio-lipids to renewable hydrocarbons. The effects of reaction time, temperature, H2 pressure and Ti/Si molar ratio have been extensively investigated by adopting ML HDO as a model reaction. Under optimal operation parameters (300 ℃, 2.5 MPa H2, 6 h, Ti/Si molar ratio = 1/1), the 10 wt%Ni-3 wt%Mo/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst afforded an n-C12 yield of 96.3% at full ML conversion. In addition, non-edible bio-lipids such as jatropha oil and waste cooking oil also converted to n-C14+16+18 alkanes with yields of 94.3% and 92.4%, respectively. The Ni-Mo bimetallic catalyst also efficiently catalyzed the HDO of different bio-lipids and presented impressive chemoselectivity which is rarely reported in previous research. Catalyst characterization indicated that the introduction of Mo as an oxophilic promoter is important for the increase of HDO activity of Ni-catalysts. It weakens strong interaction between electron-rich Ni sites and Cδ+ in Cδ+ Oδ− and/or Cδ+–Oδ− groups to form undesired carboxylate and η1(C)-acyl configurations, while simultaneously forming η2(C,O)-aldehyde configuration which benefits the formation of R–CH2OH intermediate. In addition, the formation of oxygen vacancy on TiO2 surface not only increase Ni sites dispersion but also adsorb CO to promote the conversion of R-COOCH3→R–CHO. The Brønsted acidity of the Ni-Mo bimetallic catalyst is affected by both Mo-addition (Mo4+–OH, Mo6+–OH) and Ti/Si molar ratio (bridge –OH group), and is crucial in adsorption and activation of C–O, enhancing the activity of the Ni-Mo catalyst toward the HDO of R-CH2OH intermediate. coredata.dc:description: Ni-catalysts are promising candidate for fatty acid hydrodeoxygenation (HDO), but are limited by their quite poor HDO selectivity. Herein, a mesoporous Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst was prepared by precipitation and impregnation method and used for methyl laurate HDO, yielding 96.3% n-dodecane yield at full methyl laurate conversion. Non-edible bio-lipids such as jatropha oil and waste cooking oil also converted to n-C14+16+18 hydrocarbons with yields of 94.3% and 92.4%, respectively. Besides, Ni-Mo/SiO2-TiO2 shows strong chemoselectivity towards the HDO of ester groups. Experimental results showed that Mo-addition and Ti/Si molar ratio strongly influenced HDO selectivity. Oxygen vacancies formed on partial reduced TiO2 surface securely bond Ni NPs and activate CO/CO bonds, improving Ni NPs dispersion and promoting R–COOCH3→R–CHO reduction. Additional, Mo-addition switches reactant adsorption configuration from η1(C)-acyl to η2(C,O)-aldehyde, promoting the formation of R–CH2OH intermediate. Moreover, abundant Brønsted acidic sites (Mo4+–OH, Mo6+–OH, hydroxy groups) facilitate the HDO of R-CH2OH to R-CH3.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrodeoxygenation of non-edible bio-lipids to renewable hydrocarbons over mesoporous SiO2-TiO2 supported NiMo bimetallic catalyst
